introduction: In this talk, the speaker discusses algorithmic game theory, a field that focuses on research at the intersection of computer science, game theory, and economic theory, particularly motivated by the internet. The speaker covers three different lines of work: government-regulated auctions, computational mechanism analysis, and a sabbatical project in Uganda for building a cell phone-based mobile market for agricultural commodities. The talk aims to provide a high-level overview of these topics and their importance in the field of algorithmic game theory.

sections.title: Section 1: Government-Regulated Auctions
content: Explanation of government-regulated auctions as a mechanism for repacking TV stations on a national scale.
Description of the auction process, where the government lowers prices for participating stations until they can be accommodated back to their original positions.
Discussion of the willingness of other participants and the first-price auction mechanism.
Explanation of the practicality of the auction design and the use of powerful algorithms to analyze its performance.

sections.title: Section 2: Computational Mechanism Analysis
content: Introduction to computational mechanism analysis as a method for finding the exact equilibria of compactly represented games.
Explanation of the use of powerful techniques for finding exact equilibria, such as technology from maybe five years ago.
Discussion of the application of computational mechanism analysis in various contexts, such as finding the optimal reserve price parameter for sponsored search auctions.
Explanation of the importance of computational mechanism analysis in understanding the efficiency and revenue generation of different mechanisms.

sections.title: Section 3: Sabbatical Project in Uganda
content: Presentation of a sabbatical project in Uganda for building a cell phone-based mobile market for agricultural commodities.
Description of the application of economic theory to development problems, such as allowing subsistence farmers to sell surplus produce to traders in the cities using a craigslist that runs over SMS.
Explanation of the importance of the project in addressing agricultural commodity markets and providing a platform for farmers to improve their livelihoods.
Discussion of the challenges and future directions for the project.

sections.title: Section 4: Algorithmic Game Theory and the Internet
content: Explanation of the role of algorithmic game theory in research at the interface of computer science, game theory, and economic theory, particularly motivated by the internet.
Discussion of the design of new mechanisms, analysis of existing mechanisms, and the study of specific examples, such as sponsored search auctions and computational mechanism analysis.
Explanation of the importance of algorithmic game theory in understanding the behavior of online markets and the development of efficient algorithms for game theory.
Presentation of recent work in the field and the potential for future research.

sections.title: Section 5: Computational Complexity and Algorithmic Game Theory
content: Explanation of the relationship between computational complexity and algorithmic game theory.
Discussion of the use of powerful algorithms to analyze the performance of mechanisms, such as in government-regulated auctions and computational mechanism analysis.
Explanation of the importance of computational complexity in understanding the efficiency and scalability of different mechanisms.
Presentation of recent work in the field and the potential for future research.
